canonical_explanation.text: The human respiratory system includes the nose, pharynx, larynx, trachea, bronchi, bronchioles, and alveoli in the lungs. Breathing involves inspiration (inhalation) and expiration (exhalation), driven by the diaphragm and intercostal muscles. Lung volumes and capacities include tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, residual volume, vital capacity, and total lung capacity. Gas exchange occurs at the alveolar surface by diffusion. Oxygen is transported primarily bound to haemoglobin (as oxyhaemoglobin), while CO2 is transported as bicarbonate ions (~70%), carbamino compounds (~23%), and dissolved in plasma (~7%). The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoidal. Respiration is regulated by the respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata.
rules: Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by diffusion, driven by partial pressure gradients of O2 and CO2.
Haemoglobin can bind up to four O2 molecules; binding is cooperative, producing a sigmoidal dissociation curve.
CO2 is mainly transported as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) formed by the enzyme carbonic anhydrase in RBCs.

questions.question_text: The functional units of gas exchange in the lungs are:
questions.explanation_correct: The alveoli are the functional units of gas exchange in the lungs. They are tiny air sacs where oxygen is absorbed into the bloodstream and carbon dioxide is expelled from the body during breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The alveoli, not the bronchi, trachea, or bronchioles, are the functional units of gas exchange in the lungs. The alveoli have a large surface area and thin walls that allow efficient diffusion of oxygen and carbon dioxide between the air and the blood.

questions.question_text: During inspiration, the diaphragm:

options.text: Contracts and moves downward, increasing the thoracic volume

questions.explanation_correct: During inspiration, the diaphragm contracts and moves downward, increasing the thoracic volume. This increases the space in the chest cavity, lowering the air pressure and causing air to be drawn into the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The diaphragm does not relax and move upward during inspiration, as this would decrease the thoracic volume and cause air to be pushed out of the lungs instead of being drawn in. The diaphragm also does not remain unchanged or move laterally - it specifically contracts and moves downward to increase the space in the chest cavity and allow air to be inhaled.

questions.question_text: The volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum expiration is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The residual volume is the volume of air remaining in the lungs after maximum expiration. This air cannot be expelled from the lungs and ensures that the alveoli do not collapse, allowing for continuous gas exchange.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tidal volume is the volume of air breathed in and out during normal, resting breathing. The vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be expelled from the lungs after a maximum inhalation. The inspiratory reserve volume is the additional volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal inhalation. The residual volume is the only option that refers to the air remaining in the lungs after maximum expiration.

questions.question_text: Vital capacity is:

options.text: The total volume of air in the lungs
The maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximum inhalation (TV + IRV + ERV)
The volume of air breathed in and out in normal breathing
The volume of air remaining after normal expiration

questions.explanation_correct: Vital capacity is the maximum volume of air that can be exhaled after a maximum inhalation. This includes the tidal volume (TV), inspiratory reserve volume (IRV), and expiratory reserve volume (ERV), which together make up the total volume of air that can be breathed out after a deep breath.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The total volume of air in the lungs is called the total lung capacity (TLC), not the vital capacity. The volume of air breathed in and out during normal breathing is called the tidal volume (TV), not the vital capacity. The volume of air remaining after normal expiration is called the residual volume (RV), not the vital capacity.

questions.question_text: Oxygen is primarily transported in blood by:
questions.explanation_correct: Oxygen is primarily transported in the blood bound to haemoglobin as oxyhaemoglobin. This is the most efficient way to transport oxygen, as haemoglobin can carry up to four oxygen molecules at a time.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While some oxygen is dissolved in the plasma and some is transported as bicarbonate ions, the majority of oxygen in the blood is carried bound to haemoglobin. Haemoglobin has a high affinity for oxygen and can transport much more oxygen than if it was just dissolved in the plasma. Oxygen bound to white blood cells is not a significant mode of transport.

questions.question_text: The major form in which CO2 is transported in blood is:
questions.explanation_correct: The major form in which CO2 is transported in the blood is as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-). This is because when CO2 is produced in the body's tissues, it dissolves in the blood and reacts with water to form carbonic acid (H2CO3). The carbonic acid then dissociates into bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) and hydrogen ions (H+).
questions.explanation_incorrect: While some CO2 is transported dissolved in the plasma (around 7%) and a small amount is bound to haemoglobin as carbamino compounds (around 23%), the majority of CO2 (around 70%) is transported as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-). CO2 does not get transported as carbonic acid, as it is an intermediate step in the formation of bicarbonate ions.

questions.question_text: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is:
questions.explanation_correct: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is sigmoidal (S-shaped) because haemoglobin binds oxygen cooperatively, with the binding of one oxygen molecule increasing the affinity for the next oxygen molecule.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The oxygen-haemoglobin dissociation curve is not linear, exponential, or hyperbolic. It is sigmoidal (S-shaped) because haemoglobin exhibits cooperative binding of oxygen. This means that as more oxygen binds to haemoglobin, the remaining binding sites become more likely to bind oxygen, leading to the characteristic S-shape of the curve.

questions.question_text: The Bohr effect states that an increase in CO2 concentration or a decrease in pH:

options.text: Decreases haemoglobin's affinity for O2, promoting O2 release to tissues
Has no effect on O2 binding

questions.explanation_correct: The Bohr effect states that an increase in CO2 concentration or a decrease in pH (increased acidity) decreases haemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. This promotes the release of oxygen from haemoglobin to the surrounding tissues, where oxygen is needed for cellular respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The Bohr effect does not increase haemoglobin's affinity for oxygen. In fact, it has the opposite effect - increased CO2 or decreased pH causes haemoglobin to release oxygen more easily to the tissues that need it. This is because the binding of CO2 or H+ ions to haemoglobin changes its shape, making it less able to bind oxygen tightly.

questions.question_text: Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme found in RBCs that catalyses:

options.text: The reaction CO2 + H2O â†’ H2CO3 (carbonic acid)

questions.explanation_correct: Carbonic anhydrase is an enzyme found in red blood cells (RBCs) that catalyzes the reaction where carbon dioxide (CO2) combines with water (H2O) to form carbonic acid (H2CO3). This is an important step in the transport of CO2 from the body's tissues to the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Carbonic anhydrase does not directly bind oxygen to haemoglobin, C) It does not catalyze the breakdown of glucose, and D) It does not catalyze the formation of oxyhaemoglobin. The correct answer is B, where carbonic anhydrase catalyzes the reaction between CO2 and H2O to form carbonic acid, which is a key step in the transport of CO2 in the body.

questions.question_text: The respiratory centre that controls the basic rhythm of breathing is located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: The respiratory center that controls the basic rhythm of breathing is located in the medulla oblongata, which is part of the brainstem. This is the correct answer because the medulla oblongata contains the respiratory center that coordinates the automatic, involuntary control of breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The respiratory center is not located in the cerebrum, cerebellum, or hypothalamus. These other brain regions have different functions, such as processing sensory information, coordinating movement, and regulating hormones. The medulla oblongata is the specific part of the brainstem that contains the respiratory center, which is responsible for the basic rhythm and control of breathing.

questions.question_text: Asthma is characterised by:

options.text: Narrowing of the bronchial airways due to inflammation and spasm

questions.explanation_correct: Asthma is characterized by narrowing of the bronchial airways due to inflammation and spasm, which makes it difficult to breathe. This is the correct answer, as the other options do not accurately describe the symptoms of asthma.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asthma is not characterized by infection of the alveoli, loss of alveolar walls, or lung cancer. These conditions are different respiratory disorders with distinct symptoms. Asthma specifically involves inflammation and spasms in the bronchial airways, leading to narrowing and difficulty breathing.

questions.question_text: Emphysema is a chronic condition where:

options.text: Alveolar walls are damaged, reducing the surface area for gas exchange

questions.explanation_correct: In emphysema, the alveolar walls are damaged, reducing the surface area available for gas exchange. This impairs the lungs' ability to take in oxygen and expel carbon dioxide efficiently.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Emphysema is not caused by narrowed bronchi or a blocked trachea, as these conditions are associated with other respiratory diseases. Pleural fluid accumulation is also not a characteristic of emphysema. The key feature of emphysema is the destruction of alveolar walls, which decreases the total surface area for gas exchange and makes it harder for the lungs to function properly.

questions.question_text: The tidal volume is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The tidal volume is the amount of air that is breathed in and out during normal, relaxed breathing. This is approximately 500 mL, which is the correct answer (option B).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The tidal volume is not 2500 mL (option A), 1200 mL (option C), or 3000 mL (option D). These values are too high for normal, relaxed breathing. The correct tidal volume is around 500 mL, which is the amount of air that is inhaled and exhaled during each normal breath.

questions.question_text: The partial pressure of O2 (pO2) in alveolar air is approximately:
questions.explanation_correct: The partial pressure of O2 (pO2) in alveolar air is approximately 104 mmHg. This is because the alveoli in the lungs are where gas exchange occurs, and the O2 concentration is higher in the alveoli compared to the air we breathe in.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The partial pressure of O2 (pO2) in alveolar air is approximately 104 mmHg, not 40 mmHg, 159 mmHg, or 20 mmHg. This is because the alveoli are the site of gas exchange in the respiratory system, and the O2 concentration is higher in the alveoli compared to the air we breathe in (atmospheric air) due to the diffusion of O2 from the alveoli into the bloodstream.

questions.question_text: The pleural fluid between the visceral and parietal pleura:

options.text: Reduces friction during breathing and helps in lung expansion

questions.explanation_correct: The pleural fluid between the visceral and parietal pleura reduces friction during breathing and helps in lung expansion. This fluid acts as a lubricant, allowing the lungs to easily slide against the chest wall during inhalation and exhalation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pleural fluid does not aid in digestion, carry oxygen, or produce mucus. Its main function is to reduce friction between the lungs and the chest wall, allowing the lungs to expand and contract smoothly during breathing.

questions.question_text: Occupational respiratory diseases like silicosis and asbestosis are caused by:

options.text: Long-term inhalation of dust particles (silica, asbestos fibres)

questions.explanation_correct: Occupational respiratory diseases like silicosis and asbestosis are caused by the long-term inhalation of dust particles, specifically silica and asbestos fibres. These particles can get deposited in the lungs, leading to inflammation and scarring of the lung tissue, which impairs respiratory function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Occupational respiratory diseases are not caused by viral infections, genetic disorders, or excessive exercise. These factors may contribute to other respiratory conditions, but silicosis and asbestosis are specifically due to the inhalation of harmful dust particles over a prolonged period of time. The correct answer is long-term inhalation of silica and asbestos fibres.

questions.question_text: Each haemoglobin molecule can carry a maximum of:
questions.explanation_correct: Each haemoglobin molecule can carry a maximum of 4 molecules of oxygen. This is because haemoglobin has 4 binding sites for oxygen, allowing it to transport oxygen efficiently throughout the body.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct as each haemoglobin molecule can carry a maximum of 4 molecules of oxygen. This is because haemoglobin has 4 binding sites for oxygen. The other options are incorrect as they do not represent the actual number of oxygen molecules that can bind to a single haemoglobin molecule.

questions.question_text: The voice box (organ of sound production) is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The larynx is the voice box, the organ responsible for sound production. It contains the vocal cords that vibrate to produce voice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pharynx, trachea, and bronchus are not the voice box. The larynx is the correct answer because it is the organ that contains the vocal cords, which vibrate to produce sound and voice.

questions.question_text: The pneumotaxic centre in the pons:

options.text: Moderates the respiratory rhythm by limiting the duration of inspiration

questions.explanation_correct: The pneumotaxic centre in the pons moderates the respiratory rhythm by limiting the duration of inspiration. This helps regulate the depth and rate of breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The pneumotaxic centre does not stimulate inspiration, produce surfactant, or control blood pressure. Instead, it regulates the respiratory rhythm by inhibiting the inspiratory centre in the medulla oblongata, thereby preventing over-inflation of the lungs during inhalation.

questions.question_text: The chloride shift (Hamburger's phenomenon) occurs when:

options.text: Chloride ions (Cl-) move into RBCs as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) move out, maintaining electrical neutrality

questions.explanation_correct: The chloride shift, also known as Hamburger's phenomenon, occurs when chloride ions (Cl-) move into red blood cells (RBCs) as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) move out, maintaining electrical neutrality. This exchange helps transport carbon dioxide (CO2) from the body's tissues to the lungs for exhalation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is the correct answer. The chloride shift does not occur when oxygen (O2) enters RBCs, sodium enters RBCs, or when hemoglobin is degraded. The chloride shift is specifically an exchange of chloride and bicarbonate ions across the RBC membrane, which facilitates the transport of CO2 in the blood.

questions.question_text: The C-shaped cartilaginous rings of the trachea:

options.text: Allow the trachea to collapse easily
Keep the trachea open for air passage

questions.explanation_correct: The C-shaped cartilaginous rings in the trachea keep the trachea open and rigid, allowing for the unobstructed passage of air during breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The cartilaginous rings in the trachea do not allow the trachea to collapse easily, as they provide structural support and rigidity to keep the airway open. The trachea's function is to facilitate the movement of air, not to produce mucus or participate in gas exchange, which happens in the alveoli of the lungs.

questions.question_text: Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is:

options.text: The volume inhaled after a normal inspiration
The additional volume that can be forcefully exhaled after a normal expiration
The air remaining after maximum expiration

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B, as the expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the additional volume of air that can be forcefully exhaled after a normal expiration. This extra air is present in the lungs and can be expelled through active contraction of the abdominal muscles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not accurate. A is incorrect because the volume inhaled after a normal inspiration is the tidal volume, not the expiratory reserve volume. C is incorrect because the air remaining after maximum expiration is the residual volume, not the expiratory reserve volume. D is incorrect because the normal tidal volume is the volume of air inhaled and exhaled during normal breathing, not the expiratory reserve volume.

questions.question_text: Chemoreceptors that detect changes in CO2 and H+ concentration are located in the:
questions.explanation_correct: Chemoreceptors that detect changes in CO2 and H+ concentration are located in the aortic arch and carotid body, not the lungs, kidneys, or liver. These specialized receptors monitor the composition of blood and relay this information to the respiratory control center in the brain to adjust breathing as needed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is B) Aortic arch and carotid body. These chemoreceptors are specifically located in the blood vessels near the heart and neck, where they can monitor the levels of CO2 and H+ in the blood. The lungs, kidneys, and liver do not contain these types of chemoreceptors responsible for regulating breathing.

questions.question_text: CO2 bound to the amino groups of haemoglobin is called:
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) Carbaminohaemoglobin. This is because when CO2 binds to the amino groups of haemoglobin, it forms a compound called carbaminohaemoglobin.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other options are incorrect because: A) Oxyhaemoglobin is the compound formed when oxygen binds to haemoglobin, C) Carboxyhaemoglobin is formed when carbon monoxide binds to haemoglobin, and D) Methaemoglobin is a form of haemoglobin where the iron atom is in the ferric (Fe3+) state instead of the normal ferrous (Fe2+) state.

questions.question_text: The respiratory membrane (gas exchange barrier) in the lungs consists of:

options.text: The alveolar epithelium, basement membrane, and capillary endothelium

questions.explanation_correct: The respiratory membrane (gas exchange barrier) in the lungs consists of the alveolar epithelium, basement membrane, and capillary endothelium (option B). This multi-layered structure allows for efficient diffusion of gases between the air in the alveoli and the blood in the capillaries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The respiratory membrane does not consist of thick muscular walls (option C) or cartilaginous rings (option D). These structures are part of the conducting airways (nose, trachea, bronchi) and not the actual site of gas exchange. The correct answer is option B, which includes the alveolar epithelium, basement membrane, and capillary endothelium - the three layers that make up the respiratory membrane in the lungs.

questions.question_text: A spirometer is used to measure:
questions.explanation_correct: A spirometer is used to measure lung volumes and capacities, such as tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and vital capacity. It helps assess the functioning of the respiratory system.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A spirometer does not measure blood pressure, heart rate, or body temperature. It is a specialized instrument used to measure different lung volumes and capacities, which can provide valuable information about a person's respiratory health and function.

questions.question_text: During expiration, the external intercostal muscles:

options.text: Relax, causing the ribs to move downward and inward

questions.explanation_correct: During expiration, the external intercostal muscles relax, causing the ribs to move downward and inward, reducing the volume of the thoracic cavity and allowing air to be expelled from the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The external intercostal muscles do not contract forcefully during expiration. Instead, they relax, which reduces the volume of the thoracic cavity and pushes air out of the lungs. The diaphragm and internal intercostal muscles are the ones that contract to increase the volume of the thoracic cavity during inhalation.

questions.question_text: Approximately what percentage of CO2 is transported as bicarbonate ions?
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B) 70%. This is because around 70% of the CO2 transported in the blood is in the form of bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), which are produced when CO2 reacts with water in the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is A) 23%. This is not correct because only about 23% of the CO2 transported in the blood is in the form of carbamino compounds, not bicarbonate ions. The majority, around 70%, is transported as bicarbonate ions (HCO3-), which are produced when CO2 reacts with water in the blood.

questions.question_text: Smoking is the primary cause of which respiratory disorder characterised by the destruction of alveolar walls?
questions.explanation_correct: Smoking is the primary cause of emphysema, a respiratory disorder characterized by the gradual destruction and enlargement of the alveolar walls in the lungs. This leads to a loss of surface area for gas exchange, making it harder for the person to breathe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Smoking does not primarily cause asthma, pneumonia, or tuberculosis. Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the airways, pneumonia is an infection of the lungs, and tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The correct answer is emphysema, a respiratory disorder caused by the destruction of alveolar walls, which is primarily linked to smoking.

questions.question_text: The right lung has:
questions.explanation_correct: The right lung has three lobes - the upper, middle, and lower lobes. This is the correct anatomical structure of the right lung.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that the right lung has three lobes. The left lung has two lobes, so the right lung cannot have two, four, or one lobe. The right lung is divided into three distinct lobes, which is the normal anatomical structure.

questions.question_text: At tissue level, oxyhaemoglobin releases oxygen because:

options.text: pO2 is low and pCO2 is high in tissues, lowering haemoglobin's affinity for O2

questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is B because at the tissue level, the partial pressure of oxygen (pO2) is low and the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (pCO2) is high. This lowers the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, causing it to release oxygen into the tissues that need it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answers are not correct because: A) A high pO2 in tissues would actually increase the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, causing it to hold onto the oxygen. C) A lower temperature would increase the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, again causing it to hold onto the oxygen. D) A higher pH would increase the affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, also causing it to hold onto the oxygen.

questions.question_text: Pulmonary fibrosis reduces lung compliance. This means:

options.text: Lungs become stiff and difficult to expand, reducing ventilation

questions.explanation_correct: In pulmonary fibrosis, the lungs become stiff and less compliant, making them difficult to expand during inhalation. This reduces the overall ventilation of the lungs and gas exchange, leading to respiratory difficulties.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option A is incorrect because in pulmonary fibrosis, the lungs become stiff and difficult to expand, not easy. Option C is incorrect because gas exchange is reduced in pulmonary fibrosis, not improved. Option D is incorrect because tidal volume, which is the volume of air moved in and out during normal breathing, decreases in pulmonary fibrosis due to the reduced lung compliance.

questions.question_text: Total lung capacity (TLC) equals:
questions.explanation_correct: Total lung capacity (TLC) is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold. It is equal to the vital capacity (the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled or exhaled) plus the residual volume (the amount of air left in the lungs after maximum exhalation).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Option B is correct because total lung capacity includes both the vital capacity and the residual volume. The vital capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be inhaled or exhaled, while the residual volume is the amount of air left in the lungs after maximum exhalation. Options A, C, and D do not accurately represent the full definition of total lung capacity.

questions.question_text: Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by:

options.text: Simple diffusion based on partial pressure gradients

questions.explanation_correct: Gas exchange at the alveolar surface occurs by simple diffusion based on partial pressure gradients. Oxygen diffuses from the alveolar air (higher partial pressure) into the blood (lower partial pressure), while carbon dioxide diffuses from the blood (higher partial pressure) into the alveolar air (lower partial pressure).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gas exchange does not occur by active transport, osmosis, or facilitated diffusion at the alveolar surface. Active transport requires energy expenditure to move molecules against their concentration gradient, osmosis involves the movement of water across a semi-permeable membrane, and facilitated diffusion uses specialized carrier proteins to move molecules down their concentration gradient. Instead, the exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide happens through simple diffusion driven by the partial pressure differences between the alveolar air and the blood.

questions.question_text: An increase in blood CO2 levels stimulates the respiratory centre to:

options.text: Increase the rate and depth of breathing

questions.explanation_correct: An increase in blood CO2 levels stimulates the respiratory centre in the brain to increase the rate and depth of breathing. This is because high CO2 levels indicate the need for more oxygen intake and more CO2 removal through increased respiration.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is that an increase in blood CO2 levels stimulates the respiratory centre to increase the rate and depth of breathing. This is because the respiratory centre in the brain monitors CO2 levels, and higher CO2 indicates a need for more efficient gas exchange to remove excess CO2 and take in more oxygen. Decreasing the breathing rate or stopping breathing entirely would not help remove the excess CO2, so the respiratory centre increases breathing to restore the normal CO2 levels in the blood.

questions.question_text: The left lung has three lobes while the right lung has two lobes.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct answer is false. The left lung has two lobes, while the right lung has three lobes. This is because the right lung is slightly larger than the left lung and is divided into three distinct lobes to fit within the right side of the chest cavity.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect answer is that the left lung has three lobes and the right lung has two lobes. This is not correct because the left lung actually has two lobes, while the right lung has three lobes. The division of the lungs into lobes is related to the size and positioning of the lungs within the chest cavity.

questions.question_text: Haemoglobin has a higher affinity for carbon monoxide (CO) than for oxygen.
questions.explanation_correct: Haemoglobin has a higher affinity for carbon monoxide (CO) than for oxygen. This is because CO binds to haemoglobin much more strongly than oxygen, preventing oxygen from binding and being transported in the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some people may think that haemoglobin has a higher affinity for oxygen than CO, but this is not correct. Carbon monoxide is actually able to bind to haemoglobin more easily than oxygen, preventing the transport of oxygen in the body. This is why CO poisoning can be very dangerous - it prevents the blood from carrying enough oxygen to the body's tissues.

questions.question_text: Residual volume is the volume of air that can be measured using a spirometer.
questions.explanation_correct: Residual volume is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after maximum exhalation, and cannot be measured using a spirometer. A spirometer can only measure the volumes that can be breathed in and out, not the residual volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The residual volume is the volume of air that remains in the lungs after maximum exhalation. This air cannot be expelled from the lungs and cannot be measured by a spirometer. A spirometer can only measure the volumes of air that can be breathed in and out, not the residual volume that is always left in the lungs.

questions.question_text: The respiratory rhythm is primarily controlled by the respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata.
questions.explanation_correct: The respiratory rhythm is primarily controlled by the respiratory centre located in the medulla oblongata, a part of the brainstem. This centre coordinates the rhythmic contraction and relaxation of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles to ensure regular breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Some students may think the respiratory rhythm is controlled by the heart or lungs, but this is incorrect. The respiratory centre in the medulla oblongata is the main control centre that regulates our breathing by sending signals to the muscles involved in inhalation and exhalation.

questions.question_text: Oxygen is transported mainly as bicarbonate ions in the blood.
questions.explanation_correct: Oxygen is transported primarily bound to hemoglobin in the blood, not as bicarbonate ions. Hemoglobin carries oxygen as oxyhemoglobin, which can then release oxygen to the body's tissues.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement that oxygen is transported mainly as bicarbonate ions in the blood is incorrect. Only about 7% of carbon dioxide is transported as dissolved gas in the plasma, while the majority (around 70%) is transported as bicarbonate ions. Oxygen, on the other hand, is transported primarily bound to hemoglobin as oxyhemoglobin, which is the main form of oxygen transport in the blood.

questions.question_text: The volume of air inspired or expired during normal breathing is called ___ volume.
questions.explanation_correct: The volume of air inspired or expired during normal, relaxed breathing is called the tidal volume. This is because it is the 'tide' or regular volume of air that moves in and out of the lungs during breathing.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The volume of air inspired or expired during normal breathing is not called the inspiratory reserve volume or expiratory reserve volume. Those refer to the extra volumes of air that can be inhaled or exhaled beyond the normal tidal volume. The correct term for the regular volume of air that moves in and out during breathing is the tidal volume.

questions.question_text: The enzyme in RBCs that catalyses the formation of carbonic acid from CO2 and water is ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The enzyme carbonic anhydrase is responsible for catalyzing the formation of carbonic acid (H2CO3) from carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) in red blood cells (RBCs). This is an important step in the transport of CO2 from body tissues to the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format is 'carbonic anhydrase'. This enzyme is crucial for the transport of carbon dioxide in the body. It catalyzes the reversible reaction that converts CO2 and H2O into carbonic acid, which can then be transported as bicarbonate ions, carbamino compounds, or dissolved in the plasma. Without this enzyme, the transport of CO2 would be much less efficient.

questions.question_text: Haemoglobin bound to oxygen is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Haemoglobin is the protein in red blood cells that carries oxygen. When haemoglobin binds to oxygen, it is called oxyhaemoglobin. This is the primary way that oxygen is transported in the blood.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'oxyhaemoglobin'. Haemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells. When haemoglobin is bound to oxygen, it is called oxyhaemoglobin. This is the most common way that oxygen is transported in the blood, rather than being dissolved in the plasma.

questions.question_text: The chronic condition caused by destruction of alveolar walls, commonly associated with smoking, is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The chronic condition caused by destruction of alveolar walls, commonly associated with smoking, is called emphysema. Emphysema is a lung disease that damages the alveoli, which are the tiny air sacs in the lungs where gas exchange occurs. This leads to a decreased surface area for oxygen and carbon dioxide exchange, making breathing more difficult.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'emphysema'. Emphysema is a chronic lung disease where the alveoli (air sacs) in the lungs are damaged and destroyed, usually due to long-term exposure to irritants like cigarette smoke. This reduces the surface area available for gas exchange, making it harder to breathe. The other option 'pneumonia' is a different lung condition that involves inflammation and fluid buildup in the alveoli, not destruction of the alveolar walls.

questions.question_text: The maximum volume of air a person can breathe in after a forced expiration is called the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The vital capacity is the maximum volume of air a person can breathe in after a forced expiration. This is because the vital capacity measures the total amount of air a person can inhale and exhale with maximum effort, which includes the tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, and expiratory reserve volume.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'vital capacity'. The vital capacity is not the same as the tidal volume, which is the normal volume of air inhaled and exhaled during each breathing cycle. The vital capacity is the maximum volume of air a person can forcefully inhale and exhale, which includes the tidal volume plus the additional air that can be inhaled and exhaled with maximum effort.

questions.question_text: The condition characterised by inflammation and narrowing of bronchial passages with wheezing is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the bronchial passages, leading to wheezing, is called asthma. This is the correct answer because asthma is a respiratory disorder that affects the airways, making it difficult to breathe.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The accepted answer format for this question is 'asthma'. Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition that causes the airways to swell and narrow, resulting in symptoms like wheezing, coughing, and shortness of breath. This is the correct answer because it accurately describes the condition mentioned in the question.

questions.question_text: The muscular sheet that separates the thoracic and abdominal cavities is the ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The diaphragm is the muscular sheet that separates the thoracic cavity (containing the lungs) from the abdominal cavity. It plays a crucial role in breathing by contracting and relaxing to drive air in and out of the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'diaphragm'. The diaphragm is a dome-shaped muscle that forms the floor of the thoracic cavity and the ceiling of the abdominal cavity. When the diaphragm contracts, it moves downwards, increasing the volume of the thoracic cavity and causing air to be drawn into the lungs. This is an essential mechanism for breathing.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following respiratory structures in the order air passes through them during inspiration: Alveoli, Trachea, Bronchioles, Bronchi.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order of respiratory structures during inspiration is Trachea -> Bronchi -> Bronchioles -> Alveoli. This is because air first enters the trachea, then travels through the branching bronchi and bronchioles before reaching the alveoli, where gas exchange occurs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be Alveoli -> Bronchioles -> Bronchi -> Trachea. This is wrong because air flows from the trachea to the bronchi, then the bronchioles, and finally reaches the alveoli during inhalation. The alveoli are the structures in the lungs where gas exchange takes place, so they are the final destination of the air flow, not the starting point.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following in order of decreasing partial pressure of O2: Alveolar air, Atmospheric air, Deoxygenated blood, Tissue cells.
questions.explanation_correct: The partial pressure of oxygen decreases as the gas moves from the atmosphere to the alveoli, deoxygenated blood, and finally the tissue cells. This is because oxygen is continuously being used up by the cells during respiration, resulting in a lower oxygen concentration in the deoxygenated blood and tissue cells compared to the alveolar air and atmospheric air.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct order from highest to lowest partial pressure of oxygen is: Atmospheric air, Alveolar air, Deoxygenated blood, Tissue cells. This is because atmospheric air has the highest oxygen concentration, which then decreases as oxygen is used up during the journey through the respiratory system and in the tissues. Deoxygenated blood has a lower oxygen partial pressure compared to alveolar air, and tissue cells have the lowest oxygen partial pressure as they continuously use up oxygen for cellular respiration.

questions.question_text: Arrange the following lung capacities/volumes from smallest to largest: Vital capacity, Tidal volume, Residual volume, Total lung capacity.
questions.explanation_correct: The correct order from smallest to largest is Tidal volume, Residual volume, Vital capacity, Total lung capacity. This is because Tidal volume is the smallest, representing the normal volume of air inhaled and exhaled during regular breathing. Residual volume is the amount of air that remains in the lungs even after forceful exhalation. Vital capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs, while Total lung capacity is the maximum amount of air the lungs can hold.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The incorrect order would be to place Vital capacity before Residual volume. This is wrong because Residual volume is the smaller of the two, as it represents the minimum amount of air that remains in the lungs even after forceful exhalation, while Vital capacity is the maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs.
